Subject: Arbitrary labelling / floating ID's

Ian Badcoe wrote:

>-- "positions" --
>
>Both types of position (board and rule) are achieve in the same way using 
>what I call a FID (Floating ID).  This is a single floating point value 
>stored on each item (board or rule).  When an input node wishes to find an 
>item, it uses a target FID of its own (it has two, one for rules and one 
>for boards) and simply locates the closest FID in the list of items to the 
>one it is looking for.
>
>I believe this technique (which is a form of what I call "arbitrary 
>labelling") to be very powerful, although whether 1 dimensional values are 
>sufficient, I don't yet know.  But this is a different discussion.
>  
>
Just wanted to comment on this idea of Ian's. I used a similar scheme in 
an old NEAT-like prototype back in 2000. Each genome described neurons 
and connections just as in NEAT. The difference was that each neuron had 
a position represented by a single floating point value, so effectively 
the neurons existised in a line (one dimension), each neuron gene then 
was associated with a list of connection genes, each containing a length 
value. Negative length indicated a connection back along the line, and 
positive length a forward connection. Of course there is no guarantee 
that a neuron exists at the end point of a connection so I used a 
'linking' routine that just selected the nearest neuron. I suppose you 
could specify not to link if the nearest neuron's distance is greater 
than some value.

I arrived at this scheme because the neuron genes were in fact  arranged 
in a tree structure, with their position being determined relative to 
their parent gene with only the root neuron gene having an absolute 
position defined within the genome. What this meant was that any 
sub-tree at any level could be moved around without destroying the 
network topology described by that sub-tree, and that it could 
potentially connect to other parts of the network outside the subtree, 
parts that the subtree was unaware of.

Ok there was a bit more to it than this, but essentially that's what I 
did, or tried to do anyway. One result of this scheme is that re-use or 
modularity is built in but the modules aren't fixed entities, any 
sub-tree can be considered to be a module and can be copied and pasted 
to some other point on the genome.

One notable problem was deciding on connection lengths, relative neuron 
positions for new genes etc. in relation to where all of the current 
neurons are in the decoded network. If you get this wrong then the 
system performs a very inefficient search of the search space, e.g. 
always connecting to the 'outer' neurons at the ends of the 1D space.

I can't say whether this works due to other problems with my set up, but 
it's definitely something I would like to get back to someday if I get time.

Regards,

Colin.
